poem:
Title: "In the Grip of The Crookie"

From the visual cuisine of Paris, springs a mad gastronomic flight,
Crookie, crookie, sweet invasion, in your grip we delight.
Rising with the morning light, a fresh-crumb battle fought,
A desire for one more bite - conscripted, we are caught.
"O, taste and see, the transatlantic tango," cries the eye,
While a chorus of sweet-tooth tongues hum the unending lie.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Food crazes make me want to roll my eyes. But first, pass me a crookie | Jay Rayner Parisians can be unforgivingly critical of each other where food fads are concerned. “It is a fashion, a madness,” said one Françoise d’Aubigné, when her social circle became dribblingly obsessed with the Next Big Thing. “The anxiety to eat them, the pleasure of having eaten them and the desire to eat them again” were all that anybody". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
